advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to the <a href="http://web.kyoto-inet.or.jp/people/s-oga/">PC Leaflets Museum</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href="http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage">Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://club.pep.ne.jp/~p.katsu/pasocata/index.html">P.KATSU</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Valric-Laurène was the french importer of the Spectravideo SV-318.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"compare!"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ELECTRON USER MAG #1 (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first issue of the official Electron magazine.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://home.iae.nl/users/bverhoev/" target="_blank">The Electron Lives !</a> for the picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #15</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT NOV. 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Compaq has long been recognized as the world leader in both 80386 technology and portable computing. Si it's not surprising that we would combine the two.<br> But no one expected the new Compaq Portable 386 to run at 20 MHz. And no one even dreamed that it would offer 100 MB of storage, disk caching, and much, much more...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This detailed advert presents a complete EXL-100 with all the pripherals available then (printer, disk, tape, modem, carts, etc.). <br><br> "Exelvision, the french micro-computing challenge"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICROSOFT FS II, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"The Sinclair Phenomenon"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN ADVERT (1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to John Kahler for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL CATALOGUE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>Thanks to <a href="http://blogs.linux.ie/fuzzbucket/archives/p/7/more/1/c/1/Vintage-Sinclair-QL-catalogue" target="_blank">fuzzbucket</a> for this complete QL catalogue.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> AUSTRALIAN TANDY CATALOG (1992)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>''PB 700, the extensible personal computer''</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STUPID PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>An 80's beautiful (!) woman tries to convince us that it's very exciting to work with an Alpha Plus...</blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: Microsoft Basic, editor,debugger and assembler delivered on disk
computer.description:
MikroMikko was Nokia Data's attempt to enter the business computer market. The computer has 64 KB RAM and is a CP/M operating system.
There are several models of MikroMikko 1. The one pictured here is a M6 model which has two 5.25" 640 KB disc drives. But other models differ and can have one or two disk drives (360 KB or 640 KB), and even a built-in 5 MB hard disk (model M7).
The MikroMikko 1 features high resolution graphics (800x327). It is quite heavy, the keyboard weighting alone about 2 kilograms! It was a very robust built system that was very suitable for hard environments such as schools. The machine has a linear power transformer and no fan. Cooling is done by a giant heat sink on the back side of the machine.
Ergonomics has always played a great part in the MikroMikko series and this model has a keyboard with a built-in wrist support and a very slow screen that is very comfortable even though it has a 50Hz refresh rate.
Nokia later bought Ericsson's computer division. Later ICL bought the Nokia Data from Nokia that concentrated on its key competence. This machine is peculiar in that sense that it has the old Nokia logo reminding that the company was originally making car tires besides rubber boots and cables. Computer manufacturing has ceased now in plants which made this system...
MikroMikko got several follow-ups: MikroMikko 2 had a very nice display with white background and 72Hz refresh rate. it was also the only real computer that was powered by an Intel 86186. While MM2 was partly MS-DOS compatible, MikroMikko3 was an ergonomic beauty that was fully pc-compatible.
_______
Texts and pictures from Mika Ojutkangas website. Thanks a lot!
computer.keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard with function keys and numeric keypad
computer.language: Microsoft Basic, editor,debugger and assembler delivered on disk
computer.media: Model 6: Two 5.25'' disk drives (640 KB) optional 5 MB Winchester hard-disk
computer.name: Mikro Mikko 1
computer.ports: 2 x RS-232 ports, video out, printer, keyboard
